docs.lead_paragraph: A dozen writers on the CW network's reality show ''America's Next Top Model'' walked off the job yesterday over working conditions and the lack of medical benefits on the show. About 50 people joined the strikers on a picket line outside the show's West Los Angeles offices, part of a broader effort by writers on reality shows to win working conditions equal to those of other writers. Most reality show writers -- who radically edit segments and often shape a show's dramatic arc -- are paid much less than their counterparts on scripted shows. And because they are not unionized, they generally work without health insurance, pension benefits or residual payments. The writers on ''America's Next Top Model'' have asked to be represented by the Writers Guild of America. A spokesman for the CW network said it expects the issue to be resolved in time for the opening of the fall season on Sept. 20. SHARON WAXMAN

headline.main: Arts, Briefly; Writers Go on Strike At a Reality Show
